title: Correlation interpretation in work list study

content.description: Psychologists showed participants a list of words in a language they did not know. The words were repeated to participants. Group A heard the list 3 times. Group B heard the list 8 times, and Group C heard the list 25 times. Participants rated the degree to which words in the list likely referred to something good or bad. The results provide evidence for the mere exposure effect.
content.question: Which of the following is the most appropriate conclusion?

choices.label: There is a positive correlation between the number of times an individual is exposed to novel words and increased positive associations.
Increased exposure to novel words causes increased positive associations.
Increased exposure to novel words leads to increased negative associations.
Individuals exposed to novel words fewer times were more likely to associate them with something bad.

content.answer: There is a positive correlation between the number of times an individual is exposed to novel words and increased positive associations.

skill.text: 2.C: Evaluate the appropriate use of research design elements in non-experimental methodologies.
